The documented contingency plan provided at the time of inspection did not include the following information:
1) Emergency situations such as natural disasters and animal escapes that would trigger a need for measures to be put in
action as identified in a contingency plan (though, during the inspection the licensee talked about measures that might be
necessary in these circumstances).
2) Specific tasks to be carried out in response to the identified emergency of failure of the electrical fencing in an animal
enclosure (again the licensee talked about what would be done in the event of failure of the electrical fencing).
3) How response and recovery would be handled in terms of materials, resources and training needed.
Further, the licensee, did not document review of the contingency plan annually. The last documented review was on
10/1/2023.
In the event of an unanticipated emergency or disaster, a thoroughly documented and regularly reviewed contingency
plan is essential to training personnel involved in the operation and to ensuring the health and well-being of animals.
An appropriate contingency plan that provides for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of
their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be
detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their possession) must be developed, documented, and
followed. The contingency plan must include the following:
1) Identify situations the licensee or registrant might experience that would trigger the need for the measures identified in
a contingency plan to be put into action including, but not limited to, emergencies such as electrical outages, faulty HVAC
systems, fires, mechanical breakdowns, and animal escapes, as well as natural disasters most likely to be experienced;
2) Outline specific tasks required to be carried out in response to the identified emergencies or disasters including, but not
limited to, detailed animal evacuation instructions or shelter in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup
sources of food and water as well as sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, etc.
3) Identify a chain of command and who (by name or by position title) will be responsible for fulfilling these tasks; and
4) Address how response and recovery will be handled in terms of materials, resources, and training needed.
In addition, the plan must be reviewed on at least an annual basis to ensure that it adequately addresses the criteria listed
above. That review must be documented, including documenting any amendments or changes made to their plan since
the previous year’s review.
Finally, employees must be trained on the contingency plan within 30 days of their start date and within 30 days of any
substantive changes to the contingency plan.
To be corrected by the close of business on November 10, 2025.

The metal shelter inside the black bear enclosure had several jagged edge holes and loose metal siding with sharp
edges. On the south wall, near the bottom of the shelter, there was a jagged edge hole about 6 inches long and 3 inches
wide. On the west wall of the shelter, near the bottom, there was a jagged edge hole about 6 inches long and 3 inches
wide and three other smaller jagged edge holes. Finally, there was loose metal sheeting extending from the ground to
about one foot high at the edge of the door frame on the west wall of the shelter. The jagged edge holes and the loose
metal siding could cause injury to the bear in the enclosure.
Outdoor housing facilities must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
To be corrected by the close of business on 9/26/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
